\begin{abstract}
The magnetic fields of white dwarfs distort their shape generating an
anisotropic moment of inertia.  A magnetized white dwarf which rotates
obliquely relative to the symmetry axis has a mass quadrupole moment
which varies in time, so it will emit gravitational radiation.  LISA
may be able to detect the gravitational waves from two nearby, quickly
rotating white dwarfs.
\end{abstract}

\section{Introduction
author: Jeremy S. Heyl
title: Gravitational Radiation from Strongly Magnetized White Dwarfs
